items.stem: In the FSA Level I curriculum’s context, which option best describes sustainability information for capital markets?
options: Any data about environmental or social programs regardless of financial relevance
Information on E, S, and G matters that affect a company’s financial performance but are not typically captured in traditional financial statements
Only greenhouse-gas emissions and climate scenario data disclosed by listed companies
Narrative CSR stories aimed at reputation and philanthropy

items.stem: Which is the primary reason many investors demand decision-useful sustainability information?
options: To replace audited financial statements with qualitative narratives
To improve fundamental analysis, manage risk/volatility, and inform expected returns
To comply with voluntary marketing guidelines only
Because equity markets prohibit using financial data without ESG labels

items.stem: Which TWO findings reflect research-based links between sustainability performance and investor outcomes? (Choose two)
options: Higher ESG performance is generally associated with lower earnings-per-share volatility over time
Poor sustainability performers consistently outperform on a risk-adjusted basis in the long run
Stronger sustainability practices can correlate with improved profitability drivers (e.g., cost reduction, productivity)
ESG signals have no relationship with credit events or bankruptcy risk

items.stem: Why do leading companies create internal demand for sustainability data even apart from investor pressure?
options: It primarily serves public relations with no strategic value
It supports strategic decisions, risk management, and long-term financial performance
It eliminates the need for internal controls over reporting processes
It is required to compute statutory tax liabilities

items.stem: Which TWO statements align with evidence on capital markets effects of sound sustainability practices? (Choose two)
options: Sound sustainability standards are linked to lower cost of capital for companies
ESG information is irrelevant to lenders and creditors
Sustainability performance can be a signal used by investors to avoid value-destroying events
Private markets never consider sustainability information due to limited transparency

items.stem: Across varied definitions (e.g., Brundtland, The Natural Step), what common directive underpins the concept of sustainability?
options: Maximizing short-term profits irrespective of future consequences
Ensuring today’s actions do not undermine the ability to function and thrive in the future
Preferring social objectives over all financial considerations in every case
Eliminating all industrial activity to preserve natural systems

items.stem: Which statement best describes how sustainability information can relate to price or earnings volatility?
options: Higher sustainability performance is typically associated with lower EPS and price volatility over subsequent periods
Sustainability information increases volatility because it introduces non-financial noise
Volatility is unaffected by sustainability performance; only leverage ratios matter
Only carbon data—not governance or social data—affects earnings volatility

items.stem: Investors use sustainability information for different objectives. Which TWO pairs correctly match objective and use? (Choose two)
options: Risk management → use ESG signals to anticipate earnings variability
Pure marketing → replace due diligence with sustainability reports
Return enhancement → identify efficiency or innovation drivers tied to financial performance
Liquidity creation → ESG data directly increases share float

items.stem: Which mechanism most directly explains how sustainability performance can support profitability inside firms?
options: By guaranteeing higher prices for all products
Through cost reduction, productivity gains, and risk mitigation that influence margins
By removing the need for R&D expenditures
Through mandatory public subsidies

items.stem: Place the following investor orientations on a spectrum from more ‘values-driven’ to more ‘value-driven.’ Which option lists them from left (values) to right (value)?
options: Impact-first → Thematic → ESG integration → Traditional fundamental
ESG integration → Impact-first → Thematic → Traditional fundamental
Traditional fundamental → ESG integration → Impact-first → Thematic
Thematic → Impact-first → Traditional fundamental → ESG integration

items.stem: Which pairing best links a sustainability signal to a plausible financial driver for investors?
options: Governance weaknesses → higher earnings predictability
Frequent safety incidents → potential cost increases and cash-flow at risk
Transparent, decision-useful disclosure → lower information comparability
Water-intensive operations in low-stress basins → elevated transition risk only

items.stem: Which public policy development exemplifies efforts to connect finance with sustainability and mainstream sustainability into risk management and transparency?
options: A campaign encouraging companies to publish only philanthropic activities
The EU Action Plan for Financing Sustainable Growth with initiatives on capital flows, risk management, and transparency/long-termism
Rules requiring companies to report only narrative CSR content
A prohibition on integrating sustainability data in markets

items.stem: What is a central role of the Sustainable Stock Exchanges (SSE) Initiative in the ESG ecosystem?
options: Auditing corporate financial statements
Guiding exchanges/regulators to promote responsible investment and ESG reporting by listed companies
Setting IFRS accounting standards
Rating corporate bonds using credit-risk models

items.stem: Which TWO statements are consistent with evidence on corporate finance and sustainability? (Choose two)
options: Sound sustainability practices are associated with better access to and cost of capital
ESG data cannot influence lenders’ assessment of risk
Executives widely recognize links between sustainability and business success
Sustainability performance is irrelevant to long-term strategy

items.stem: Large-sample reviews of empirical research generally suggest what about the relationship between sustainability and corporate financial performance?
options: The majority of studies find a non-negative or positive relationship
Most studies find a negative relationship
There is unanimous evidence of no relationship
Only studies in private markets show any relationship

items.stem: Which TWO statements would most support investors’ demand for decision-useful sustainability information—rather than volume for its own sake? (Choose two)
options: Comparability and reliability are needed so investors can integrate ESG into analysis
More pages of narrative always increase usefulness regardless of content quality
Signals that help anticipate volatility or default risk serve investor decision-making
Information should prioritize marketing value over financial relevance

items.stem: Arrange the following high-level demand drivers in a logical chain from cause to effect for capital-markets use of sustainability information: (1) Recognition of financial relevance, (2) Growing investor & corporate demand, (3) Need for standards to ensure decision-useful information, (4) Broader adoption and market integration.
Within the Study Guide’s conventions, how are the terms ‘sustainability’ and ‘ESG’ generally treated (outside of Chapter 7’s specific discussion)?
options: They are used interchangeably when referring to investor-focused sustainability information
They are strictly distinct and never overlap
‘ESG’ refers only to governance; ‘sustainability’ excludes governance
They are avoided in favor of sector codes only

items.stem: Beyond companies and investors, which TWO types of institutions have helped shape demand for sustainability disclosure? (Choose two)
options: Public policymakers and regulators issuing disclosure guidance
Industry bodies and market associations promoting common practices
Private family offices operating in total secrecy only
Organizations focused exclusively on philanthropy reporting with no capital-markets link

items.stem: At a high level, why does the market call for sustainability disclosure standards in the first place?
options: To ensure investor-focused information is comparable, reliable, and decision-useful across companies
To eliminate financial reporting and replace it with ESG narratives
To mandate identical sustainability strategies for all firms
To limit access to capital for firms in certain industries by default

answerKey.explanation: The curriculum frames sustainability information as E, S, and G matters with financial relevance not fully captured by traditional financial statements.
Investors use ESG data to enhance fundamental analysis, manage risk and volatility, and inform expected returns.

Evidence links higher ESG to lower EPS/price volatility and to profitability drivers like cost and productivity; blanket outperformance of poor performers or ‘no link to credit events’ is not supported.
Companies create internal demand to support strategy, risk management, and long-term performance, beyond mere PR.
Studies show links to lower cost of capital and to avoiding value-destructive events; lenders and private markets do use sustainability signals.
A common directive across definitions is not compromising future ability to function and thrive.
Higher sustainability performance has been associated with lower subsequent EPS/price volatility.
Risk management uses ESG to anticipate variability; return enhancement uses efficiency/innovation drivers; the other options are not accurate.
Profitability channels include cost reduction, productivity, risk mitigation, and revenue opportunities.
Impact-first (values-oriented) → Thematic → ESG integration → Traditional fundamental (value-oriented) reflects the spectrum described in the guide.
Operational safety incidents plausibly drive costs and cash-flow risk; other pairings contradict decision-useful logic or misclassify risks.
The EU Action Plan links capital flows, risk management, and transparency/long-termism as pillars to connect finance and sustainability.
The SSE Initiative builds capacity for exchanges/regulators to promote responsible investment and ESG reporting.
Evidence connects sustainability with cost of capital/access and executives recognize links to business success.
Meta-reviews indicate a generally non-negative/positive relationship between sustainability and financial performance.
Investors need comparability/reliability and signals tied to volatility/default risk; volume without quality or marketing-only focus is insufficient.
Recognition of financial relevance → demand → need for standards → broad adoption is the logical chain described in Part I.
The Preface notes ‘sustainability’ and ‘ESG’ are used interchangeably for investor-focused usage outside Ch. 7.
Policy/regulation and industry bodies/associations both shape demand and practices around ESG disclosure.
Standards aim to ensure information is comparable, reliable, and decision-useful for investors across companies.
